metadata.title: Presumed periventricular venous infarction on magnetic resonance imaging and its association with increased white matter edema in CADASIL
metadata.abstract: Objectives Venous pathology could contribute to the development of parenchymal lesions in cerebral autosomal-dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL). We aim to identify presumed periventricular venous infarction (PPVI) in CADASIL and analyze the associations between PPVI, white matter edema, and microstructural integrity within white matter hyperintensities (WMHs) regions. Methods We included forty-nine patients with CADASIL from a prospectively enrolled cohort. PPVI was identified according to previously established MRI criteria. White matter edema was evaluated using the free water (FW) index derived from diffusion tensor imaging (DTI), and microstructural integrity was evaluated using FW-corrected DTI parameters. We compared the mean FW values and regional volumes with different levels of FW (ranging from 0.3 to 0.8) in WMHs regions between the PPVI and non-PPVI groups. We used intracranial volume to normalize each volume. We also analyzed the association between FW and microstructural integrity in fiber tracts connected with PPVI. Results We found 16 PPVIs in 10 of 49 CADASIL patients (20.4). The PPVI group had larger WMHs volume (0.068 versus 0.046, p  0.036) and higher FW in WMHs (0.55 versus 0.52, p  0.032) than the non-PPVI group. Larger areas with high FW content were also found in the PPVI group (threshold: 0.7, 0.47 versus 0.37, p  0.015; threshold: 0.8, 0.33 versus 0.25, p  0.003). Furthermore, higher FW correlated with decreased microstructural integrity (p  0.009) in fiber tracts connected with PPVI. Conclusions PPVI was associated with increased FW content and white matter degeneration in CADASIL patients. Clinical relevance statement PPVI is an important factor related with WMHs, and therefore, preventing the occurrence of PPVI would be beneficial for patients with CADASIL. Key Points Presumed periventricular venous infarction is important and occurs in about 20 of patients with CADASIL. Presumed periventricular venous infarction was associated with increased free water content in the regions of white matter hyperintensities. Free water correlated with microstructural degenerations in white matter tracts connected with the presumed periventricular venous infarction. Keywords CADASIL  Cerebral small vessel diseases  Brain edema  White matter  Magnetic resonance imaging Xinfeng Yu and Xinzhen Yin contributed equally.

Introduction.text:
Cerebral autosomal-dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL) is a rare hereditary cerebral small vessel disease (CSVD) caused by mutations in the NOTCH3 gene 1. Early studies estimated that the prevalence of NOTCH3 mutations was around 2-4100,000, but some recent studies demonstrated a much higher rate at 1 in 300-500 2. CADASIL has many similarities to sporadic CSVD with lacunar infarcts and white matter hyperintensities (WMHs), and thus, it can serve as a model to explore the pathogenesis of CSVD 3. Nevertheless, the exact mechanisms of subcortical infarcts and WMHs have not been fully understood in CADASIL.
Subcortical infarct is usually assumed to be caused by an interruption of blood flow due to arterial abnormalities such as atherosclerosis or lipohyalinosis 4. However, venous pathology may also lead to subcortical infarcts. A recent postmortem study of patients with Alzheimers disease has reported that most periventricular infarctions are related to venous collagenosis, rather than arteriolosclerosis 5. Several CADASIL studies have observed venous collagenosis and decreased density of medullary veins in the regions of periventricular WMHs 6,7. Furthermore, electron microscopy analysis revealed granular osmiophilic material (the pathological hallmark of CADASIL) deposition in both cerebral arteries and veins 8. Hitherto, little is known about periventricular venous infarction (PVI) in CADASIL.
The cerebral venous system plays an essential role in removing metabolic waste and regulating the balance of interstitial fluid (ISF) 9. ISF flows out of the brain through the veins and perivenous spaces 10,11. It also spreads along white matter tracts 12. Venous infarction in the deep white matter could cause increased hydrostatic pressure in upstream capillaries 13 and impair the ISF efflux pathways, resulting in the development of interstitial edema (i.e., extracellular edema) 14, which may further lead to fiber tract degeneration 15. Indeed, several recent studies showed increased water content in the white matter of CADASIL patients 16,17. Therefore, exploring the relationship between PVI and extracellular edema in WMHs regions has important implications for understanding the pathologies of white matter degeneration in CADASIL.
In the present study, we first studied the frequency of presumed PVI (PPVI) using MRI criteria in a cohort of CADASIL patients. Second, we analyzed the association between PPVI and extracellular edema within WMHs. Third, we investigated the relationship between extracellular edema and microstructural degenerations in white matter tracts connecting the PPVI. We hypothesized that PPVI would be associated with a higher burden of extracellular edema within WMHs, and white matter edema would correlate with microstructural degenerations in white matter tracts connected with the PPVI.

Patients.text: The study was approved by the Medical Ethics Committee of the Second Affiliated Hospital, Zhejiang University School of Medicine. Written informed consents were obtained from all patients. Forty-nine patients with CADASIL from a prospective study between October 2013 and November 2021 were included in this study (Figure S1). The diagnosis of CADASIL was confirmed by genetic testing showing a pathogenic mutation in the NOTCH3 gene 18. Clinical information was recorded, including vascular risk factors, clinical symptoms, and disease duration.

MRI acquisition and imaging processing.text: The detailed parameters of MRI sequences are listed in the supplementary materials. The steps of PPVI segmentation, PPVI-based tractography, WMHs segmentation, and classification are displayed in Figure S2.

Tractography through PPVI.text: We tracked white matter tracts through PPVI using the disconnectome map tool of the BCBtoolkit software (http: toolk it. bcblab. com). Each PPVI mask was normalized into the Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) space by applying the transformation matrix derived from registering the T1WI image to a brain template in the MNI space (1 mm 3 ) using Advanced Normalization Tools (ANTs). Then, white matter tracts passing through each PPVI were reconstructed based on ten healthy controls tractography results 23. For each PPVI, tractography maps of the ten healthy controls were binarized and averaged together so that each voxel represented a probability of fiber pathways from 0 to 1 23. The mask of fiber pathways connecting the PPVI (FCI) was created by applying a threshold of 0.5. Both PPVI and FCI were then warped from the MNI space to the native diffusion space using the b  0 smm 2 (b0) image as the reference image.

WMHs segmentation and partition.text: WMHs were segmented on FLAIR images using Lesion Segmentation Toolbox version 3.0.0 in SPM12 24. A binary WMHs mask was obtained by a threshold of 0.5 25 and further visually checked and manually corrected for false positives and negatives by an experienced radiologist (X.F.Y.) using the ITK-SNAP software (http: www. itksn ap. org). Then, the WMHs mask was co-registered with the b0 Therefore, the rim sign on SWI images could be helpful to differentiate lacunes from PPVI, although both of them have similar signals on T1WI and FLAIR images. MRI, magnetic resonance imaging; PPVI, periventricular venous infarction; T1WI, T1-weighted imaging; FLAIR, fluid-attenuated inversion recovery; SWI, susceptibility weighted imaging image by applying the transformation matrix of registration from the FLAIR image to the b0 image using ANTs. The final WMHs mask was further checked by the same radiologist (X.F.Y.). Because all PPVIs were located within WMHs, PPVI (b0 space) was dilated by one voxel in three dimensions and then removed from the WMHs mask. Both WMHs volume and ICV-corrected WMHs volume were measured. To perform analyses of extracellular edema along FCI, we divided WMHs into two subregions: FCI within WMHs (WMHs  FCI) and WMHs without FCI (WMHs -FCI).

Diffusion parameter estimation.text:
Extracellular edema was evaluated by the parameter of free water (FW) estimated from DTI images 17. The preprocessed diffusion data were fitted with a bi-tensor model within each voxel as previously described 26. In addition to FW, FW-corrected DTI parameters, namely fractional anisotropy (FAt) and mean diffusivity (MDt), and conventional DTI parameters, including FA and MD, were obtained. The FW, FA, and FAt are dimensionless, and MD and MDt are in units of 10 -3 mm 2 s. The mean values of FW, FAt, MDt, FA, and MD were extracted from the masks of WMHs, WMHs  FCI, and WMHs -FCI for each patient. For patients with two or more PPVIs, the values of diffusion parameters in WMHs  FCI were averaged.
Considering the heterogeneous distribution of extracellular edema, we analyzed the FW volume in the regions of WMHs using different FW thresholds ranging from 0.3 to 0.8 (Figure S3). The thresholds of FW were determined by the range of FW values in WMHs 17. Next, the volume of FW at each FW threshold was calculated and further adjusted by ICV.

Evaluations of lacunes and microbleeds.text: According to the STRIVE criteria 27, lacunes were defined as round or ovoid, subcortical, fluid-filled (similar signal as CSF) cavities (3 to 15 mm in diameter) thought to be present in the territory of a perforating arteriole (Fig. 1B). Lacunes are ringed by hemosiderin which appears hypointense on SWI images 28. The number of lacunes was counted in three regions, including supratentorial white matter, deep gray matter, and brainstem. Microbleeds were defined as small (diameter  10 mm) and rounded hypointense lesions on SWI images. Microbleed mimics, such as vessels and calcifications, were carefully excluded 27. Both lacunes and microbleeds were evaluated by two radiologists (X.F.Y. and X.D.) who were blinded to clinical information.

Statistics.text: Statistical analyses were performed using R (version 4.0.3) and SPSS (version 26.0). Inter-rater agreement between the two raters was calculated for the presence of PPVI (Cohens kappa) and the number of lacunes (intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC): two-way random effects model, single measurement, absolute agreement). Continuous variables are shown as mean with standard deviation (SD) or median with interquartile range (IQR), whereas categorical variables are presented as absolute and relative frequencies. We compared demographic, clinical, and neuroradiological variables between the PPVI and non-PPVI groups using Students t test or Mann-Whitney U test for continuous variables and Fishers exact test for categorical data. We used linear mixed-effects models to compare the volumes of regions with different FW thresholds between the PPVI and non-PPVI groups, adjusting for WMHs volume and disease duration. Because FW volumes were not normally distributed, both FW volumes and ICV-corrected FW volumes were log10 transformed. We used Bonferronis correction to adjust for multiple comparisons and reported Bonferroni-corrected p values. We used paired t tests to examine the differences in diffusion parameters between WMHs  FCI and WMHs -FCI in the PPVI group. The effect size for mean difference (M diff  WMHs  FCI minus WMHs -FCI) in each diffusion metric was computed, and the corresponding 95 CI was constructed by bootstrapped resampling for 5000 resamples 29. All comparisons between groups are presented using Gardner-Altman plots by Data Analysis with a Bootstrappedcoupled ESTimation package 29. The relationships between FW with FA, MD, FAt, and MDt in WMHs  FCI and WMHs -FCI regions were analyzed using Pearsons correlation and partial correlation analyses. A p value  0.05 (two-tailed) was considered statistically significant.

Patients with PPVI.text: Ten of the 49 patients (20.4) had at least one PPVI. The inter-rater agreement for detecting the presence of PPVI was excellent (kappa  0.86, 95 CI  0.68-1.00). All PPVIs were located at the center of periventricular WMHs. Five patients had a single PPVI, four patients had 2 PPVIs, and one patient had 3 PPVIs. Seven lesions (43.8) were on the left side, and nine lesions (56.2) were on the right side. In the PPVI group, no significant difference was found in the lesion volume between patients with left-sided and rightsided PPVIs (p  0.210, Figure S4).

Comparisons between the PPVI and non-PPV.text: The clinical and imaging characteristics of the PPVI and non-PPVI groups are shown in Table 1. No significant 1 3 differences were found between the two groups in clinical symptoms, including transient ischemic attackstroke (p  0.731), headache (p  0.090), cognitive deficits (p  0.261), and psychiatric disorders (p  0.720). The PPVI group had longer disease duration (p  0.043), larger ICVcorrected WMHs volume (p  0.036), and higher values of FW (p  0.032) and MD (p  0.024) in WMHs. The total numbers of lacunes in the supratentorial white matter, deep gray matter, and brainstem were 171, 17, and 9, respectively. The inter-rater reliability for the number of lacunes was excellent (supratentorial white matter, ICC  0.93, 95 CI  0.88-0.96; deep gray matter, ICC  0.82, 95 CI  0.65-0.91; brainstem, ICC  0.87, 95 CI  0.78-0.93). In the supratentorial white matter, four lacunes were outside WMHs, and 167 lacunes were at the edge of WMHs. There were no significant differences in the number of lacunes in each region between the two groups.

Increased FW in the PPVI group.text: Compared with non-PPVI, the PPVI group had significantly larger FW volumes and ICV-corrected FW volumes at FW thresholds of 0.7 (p  0.036 and p  0.015) and 0.8 (p  0.007 and p  0.003) (Fig. 2). No significant differences were found in the volume of areas with FW thresholds ranging 0.3 to 0.6. The examples of PPVI and non-PPVI cases are shown in Fig. 3. In the PPVI group, the PPVI volume was associated with the volume of FW regions at different thresholds (Table S1).

Increased FW in white matter tracts conn.text:
Figure 4 shows the comparisons of diffusion parameters between WMHs  FCI and WMHs -FCI subregions in the PPVI group. FW (M diff  0.0769, 95 CI 0.0429; 0.11, p  0.0001), MDt (M diff  0.000995, 95 CI 0.00024; 0.00172, p  0.001), and MD (M diff  0.159, 95 CI 0.0866; 0.227, p  0.0001) were significantly higher and FA (M diff  -0.0362, 95 CI -0.0544; -0.0207, p  0.0001) was significantly lower in WMHs  FCI. FAt (M diff  -0.00929, 95 CI -0.0284; 0.0091, p  0.266) showed no significant difference between the two subregions. Relative to WMHs in non-PPVI, WMHs  FCI also exhibited
significantly higher FW (p  0.0001), MD (p  0.0001), and MDt (p  0.0001) and lower FA (p  0.0001). On the other hand, WMHs -FCI showed no significant differences in diffusion parameters (Figure S5). Increased FW was associated with a decrease in FA and an increase in MD and MDt in both WMHs  FCI and WMHs -FCI (Fig. 5). After correction of age, sex, ICVcorrected PPVI volume, and ICV-corrected WMHs volume, FW remained to be associated with MD (r  0.998, p  0.0001) and MDt (r  0.921, p  0.009) in WMHs  FCI, while in WMHs -FCI, FW was only associated with MD (r  0.998, p  0.001).

Discussion.text:
Our study used MRI criteria to identify PPVI in CADASIL and found that PPVI was associated with increased extracellular edema in the regions of WMHs. Furthermore, extracellular edema correlated with microstructural degenerations in white matter tracts connecting the PPVI.
PPVI existed in 20.4 of the patients. While PPVI and lacunes showed similar signals on conventional MR images, they exhibited different features on SWI images. PPVI had punctate hypointensities within the lesion, while lacunes usually had hypointense rims around the lesion. Furthermore, we found that PPVI mainly occurred at the center of WMHs, but lacunes were located at the edge of WMHs. The spatial relationship between lacunes and WMHs was consistent with a previous study 30. These findings provided additional clues to identify PPVI.
Our unexpected finding was that PPVI had no association with the clinical symptoms, including transient ischemic attack or stroke, headache, cognitive deficits, and psychiatric disorders. It was possibly because neurological signs and symptoms are highly variable and even asymptomatic after cerebral vein occlusion 13. A variety of factors, such as sex, lesion location, lacunes, and microbleeds, are also related to clinical symptoms 3, which might have covered the effect of PPVI.
Venous collagenosis has been recognized as a contributor to WMHs 5,6. It can lead to thickened vessel walls and venous hypertension, resulting in impaired ISF drainage and decreased cerebral blood flow 31. In sporadic CSVD, we have found that disrupted medullary veins were associated with increased ISF in the periventricular white matter 32. As a more severe form of venous pathology, PVI could not only cause increased hydrostatic pressure in upstream capillaries but also interrupt ISF drainage pathways, including perivenous spaces and white matter tracts. These pathologies would together cause extracellular edema 14. In line with these theories, we found that PPVI was associated with a higher burden of extracellular edema within WMHs.
We also found that extracellular edema was more pronounced and correlated with microstructural injury in white matter tracts connecting the PPVI. Interestingly, altered fluid mobility and water content might precede fiber tract damage 17, and reversing these pathologies might slow down the degeneration process 15. Nevertheless, further longitudinal studies are still needed to confirm the possible causal relationships.
The cause of PVI may be complicated. Venous collagenosis has been observed in the regions of periventricular infarcts in a recent postmortem study 5, suggesting that venous collagenosis may contribute to the development of PVI. From a genetic perspective, cerebral venous infarctions in adults are commonly secondary to cerebral venous thrombosis 33. Damage to the endothelial cell of the veins, Fig. 5 A-D The associations between FW and other diffusion parameters in subregions of WMHs  FCI and WMHs -FCI in the PPVI group. The dashed lines represent the mean values. The MD and MDt are in units of 10 -3 mm 2 s. p  0.05; p  0.005; p  0.001. NS., not significant; FW, free water; WMHs, white matter hyperintensities; FCI, fiber pathways connecting the PPVI; WMHs  FCI, FCI within WMHs; WMHs -FCI, WMHs without FCI; PPVI, presumed periventricular venous infarction; MD, mean diffusivity; MDt, tissue compartment MD; FA, fractional anisotropy; FAt, tissue compartment FA caused by the NOTCH3 gene mutations, seems to take part in venous thrombosis in CADASIL 34. Besides, the upregulation of collagen in the venule wall would also promote local thrombosis 35. Therefore, venous collagenosis and thrombosis may co-exist before the formation of PVI.
Our study has several limitations. First, we identified PPVI according to the MRI criteria, and there was no histopathological confirmation. Future studies could analyze the accuracy of MRI criteria for identifying PPVI in animal models of CADASIL. Second, all patients were recruited from a single center, potentially producing biased results. It remains unknown whether the incidence of PPVI is underestimated or overestimated, although predisposition to PPVI may have a genetic basis 33. Multicenter studies are needed to validate our findings. Third, this is a cross-sectional study. Although there was an association between PPVI and extracellular edema within WMHs, it is still difficult to confirm a causal effect. Longitudinal studies are required to investigate the temporal relationship between PPVI and extracellular edema. Fourth, it should be noted that all PPVIs were detected at the chronic stage regarding their imaging characteristics. However, capturing the acute stage of PPVI seems to be difficult because patients with PPVI can present with non-specific symptoms, such as headaches. Last, the sample size is small, which limits the usage of multivariate analysis.
In conclusion, PPVI occurs in about 20 of patients with CADASIL and it was associated with a higher burden of extracellular edema within WMHs. Furthermore, extracellular edema correlated with microstructural degenerations in white matter tracts connected with PPVI. These results highlighted the importance of PPVI for white matter degeneration in CADASIL, which may help future preventive trials.
